items.title: Rogers nets twice as Villa come from behind to beat Leeds
items.summary: Morgan Rogers scores a second-half double as Aston Villa fight back to beat Leeds 2-1 at Elland Road and leave Daniel Farke's side in the relegation zone.

items.title: Valve says that the Steam Machine's price will be more 'in line with current PC market'
items.summary: Valve shook up the gaming world with the announcement of the Steam Machine, but we're all still curious about the million-dollar question of pricing. While there's plenty of speculation, we finally have some sort of indication from Valve directly. In an interview with Skill Up's Friends Per Second â€¦

items.summary: Amazon is selling the Echo Spot smart speaker for just $50 as part of a Black Friday promotion. The sale applies to multiple colorways and represents a discount of $30. This isn't a record low price, but it's extremely close. For the uninitiated, the Echo Spot is a diminutive little speaker/alarm câ€¦

items.title: iOS 27 will reportedly focus on performance improvements and AI upgrades
items.summary: After years of introducing major changes with its annual iOS releases, Apple may be altering its approach next time around, instead focusing on refinement over a bevy of flashy new features. According to Mark Gurman in this week's Power On newsletter, for iOS 27, Apple is "focused on improving the â€¦

items.title: This hacker conference installed a literal antivirus monitoring system
items.summary: Organizers had a way for attendees to track CO2 levels throughout the venueâ€”even before they arrived.
items.body: Hacker conferencesâ€”like all conventionsâ€”are notorious for giving attendees a parting gift of mystery illness. To combat â€œcon crud,â€ New Zealandâ€™s premier hacker conference, Kawaiicon, quietly launched a real-time, room-by-room carbon dioxide monitoring system for attendees. To get the system up and running, event organizers installed DIY CO 2 monitors throughout the Michael Fowler Centre venue before conference doors opened on November 6. Attendees were able to check a public online dashboard for clean air readings for session rooms, kidsâ€™ areas, the front desk, and more, all before even showing up. â€œItâ€™s ALMOST like we are all nerds in a risk-based industry,â€ the organizers wrote on the conventionâ€™s website. â€œWhat they did is fantastic,â€ Jeff Moss, founder of the Defcon and Black Hat security conferences, told WIRED. â€œCO 2 is being used as an approximation for so many things, but there are no easy, inexpensive network monitoring solutions available. Kawaiicon building something to do this is the true spirit of hacking.â€ Read full article Comments

items.body: We all know streaming servicesâ€™ usual tricks for making more money: get more subscribers, charge those subscribers more money, and sell ads. But science streaming service Curiosity Stream is taking a new route that could reshape how streaming companies, especially niche options , try to survive. Discovery Channel founder John Hendricks launched Curiosity Stream in 2015. The streaming service costs $40 per year, and it doesnâ€™t have commercials. The streaming business has grown to also include the Curiosity Channel TV channel. CuriosityStream Inc. also makes money through original programming and its Curiosity University educational programming. The firm turned its first positive net income in its fiscal Q1 2025, after about a decade of business. Read full article Comments

items.title: Return to the year 2000 with classic multiplayer DOS games in your browser
items.summary: There are fan-made browser versions of Red Alert, Unreal Tournament, and more.
items.body: Over the past couple of weeks, friends and colleagues have made me aware of multiple ingeniously implemented, browser-based ways to play classic MS-DOS and Windows games with other people on basically any hardware. The late 1990s and early 2000s were the peak of multiplayer gaming for me. It was the era of real-time strategy games and boomer shooters, and not only did I attend many LAN parties, but I also played online with friends. Thatâ€™s still possible today with several old-school games; there are Discord servers that arrange scheduled matches of Starsiege Tribes , for example. But oftentimes, itâ€™s not exactly trivial to get those games running in modern Windows, and as in the old days, you might have some annoying network configuration work ahead of youâ€”to say nothing of the fact that many folks who were on Windows back in those days are now on macOS or Linux instead. Read full article Comments

items.title: How to know if your Asus router is one of thousands hacked by China-state hackers
items.summary: So far, the hackers are laying low, likely for later use.
items.body: Thousands of Asus routers have been hacked and are under the control of a suspected China-state group that has yet to reveal its intentions for the mass compromise, researchers said. The hacking spree is either primarily or exclusively targeting seven models of Asus routers, all of which are no longer supported by the manufacturer, meaning they no longer receive security patches, researchers from SecurityScorecard said . So far, itâ€™s unclear what the attackers do after gaining control of the devices. SecurityScorecard has named the operation WrtHug. Staying off the radar SecurityScorecard said it suspects the compromised devices are being used similarly to those found in ORB (operational relay box) networks, which hackers primarily use to conduct espionage to conceal their identity. Read full article Comments

items.title: Google tells employees it must double capacity every 6 months to meet AI demand
items.summary: Google's AI infrastructure chief tells staff it needs thousandfold capacity increase in 5 years.
items.body: While AI bubble talk fills the air these days, with fears of overinvestment that could pop at any time, something of a contradiction is brewing on the ground: Companies like Google and OpenAI can barely build infrastructure fast enough to fill their AI needs. During an all-hands meeting earlier this month, Googleâ€™s AI infrastructure head Amin Vahdat told employees that the company must double its serving capacity every six months to meet demand for artificial intelligence services, reports CNBC. The comments show a rare look at what Google executives are telling its own employees internally. Vahdat, a vice president at Google Cloud, presented slides to its employees showing the company needs to scale â€œthe next 1000x in 4-5 years.â€ While a thousandfold increase in compute capacity sounds ambitious by itself, Vahdat noted some key constraints: Google needs to be able to deliver this increase in capability, compute, and storage networking â€œfor essentially the same cost and increasingly, the same power, the same energy level,â€ he told employees during the meeting. â€œIt wonâ€™t be easy but through collaboration and co-design, weâ€™re going to get there.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: AI trained on bacterial genomes produces never-before-seen proteins
items.summary: Genes with related functions cluster together, and the AI uses that.
items.body: AI systems have recently had a lot of success in one key aspect of biology: the relationship between a proteinâ€™s structure and its function. These efforts have included the ability to predict the structure of most proteins and to design proteins structured so that they perform useful functions . But all of these efforts are focused on the proteins and amino acids that build them. But biology doesnâ€™t generate new proteins at that level. Instead, changes have to take place in nucleic acids before eventually making their presence felt via proteins. And information at the DNA level is fairly removed from proteins, with lots of critical non-coding sequences, redundancy, and a fair degree of flexibility. Itâ€™s not necessarily obvious that learning the organization of a genome would help an AI system figure out how to make functional proteins. But it now seems like using bacterial genomes for the training can help develop a system that can predict proteins, some of which donâ€™t look like anything weâ€™ve ever seen before. Read full article Comments

items.title: Tech company CTO and others indicted for exporting Nvidia chips to China
items.summary: Four arrested and charged with illegal exports, smuggling, and money laundering.
items.body: The US crackdown on chip exports to China has continued with the arrests of four people accused of a conspiracy to illegally export Nvidia chips. Two US citizens and two nationals of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China (PRC), all of whom live in the US, were charged in an indictment unsealed on Wednesday in US District Court for the Middle District of Florida. The indictment alleges a scheme to send Nvidia â€œGPUs to China by falsifying paperwork, creating fake contracts, and misleading US authorities,â€ John Eisenberg, assistant attorney general for the Justice Departmentâ€™s National Security Division, said in a press release yesterday. The four arrestees are Hon Ning Ho (aka Mathew Ho), a US citizen who was born in Hong Kong and lives in Tampa, Florida; Brian Curtis Raymond, a US citizen who lives in Huntsville, Alabama; Cham Li (aka Tony Li), a PRC national who lives in San Leandro, California; and Jing Chen (aka Harry Chen), a PRC national who lives in Tampa on an F-1 non-immigrant student visa. Read full article Comments

items.title: Data-driven sport: How Oracle Red Bull Racing and AT&T move terabytes of F1 info
items.summary: Since the last time we spoke to the F1 team, its cars have 3 times as many sensors on them.
items.body: AT&T provided flights from Washington, DC, to Las Vegas and accommodation so Ars could attend the Las Vegas Grand Prix. Ars does not accept paid editorial content. LAS VEGASâ€”A Formula 1 car runs on soon-to-be-synthetic gasoline, but an F1 team runs on data. Itâ€™s always been an engineering-driven sport, and while you can make decisions based on a hunch, the kinds of people who become good engineers prefer something a little more convincing. And the volumes of data just continue to get bigger and bigger each season. A few years ago, we spoke to Red Bull Racing about how it stayed on top of the task, but a lot has changed in F1 since 2017, as we found out at this yearâ€™s Las Vegas Grand Prix. Itâ€™s hugely popular now, for one thing, even in the United States: a 200 mph soap opera now with 24 episodes a season. Superficially, the cars look the sameâ€”exposed wheels, front and rear wings, the driver in between some side pods. And the hybrid powertrains that make the cars move are still the same format: 1.6 L turbocharged V6 engines that recover energy from the rear wheels under braking as well as the turbine as it gets spun by hot exhaust gases. But the cars are actually fundamentally â€¦

items.summary: Tech firms dare to dream chip tariffs may go away amid rumors of delays.
items.body: For months, the Trump administration has warned that semiconductor tariffs are coming soon, leaving the tech industry on pins and needles after a chaotic year of unpredictable tariff regimes collectively cost firms billions. The semiconductor tariffs are key to Donald Trumpâ€™s economic agenda, which is intended to force more manufacturing into the US by making it more expensive to import materials and products. He campaigned on axing the CHIPS Act â€”which provided subsidies to companies investing in manufacturing chips in the USâ€”complaining that it was a â€œhorrible, horrible thingâ€ to â€œgive hundreds of billions of dollarsâ€ away when the US could achieve the same objective by instead taxing companies and â€œuse whatever is left overâ€ of CHIPS funding to â€œreduce debt.â€ However, as 2025 winds down, the US president faces pressure on all sides to delay semiconductor tariffs, insiders told Reuters , and it appears that he is considering caving. According to â€œtwo people with direct knowledge of the matter and a third person briefed on the conversations,â€ US officials have privately told industry and government stakeholders that semiconductor tariffs will likely be delayed. items.title: Chris Hemsworth and dad fight Alzheimerâ€™s with a trip down memory lane
items.summary: Ars chats with director Tom Barbor-Might about new National Geographic documentary A Road Trip to Remember.
items.body: Millions of people around the world are living with the harsh reality of Alzheimerâ€™s disease, which also significantly impacts family members. Nobody is immune, as A-list actor Chris Hemsworth discovered when his own father was recently diagnosed. The revelation inspired Hemsworth to embark on a trip down memory lane with his father, which took them to Australiaâ€™s Northern Territory . The experience was captured on film for A Road Trip to Remember, a new documentary film from National Geographic. Director Tom Barbor-Might had worked with Hemsworth on the latterâ€™s documentary series Limitless , also for National Geographic. Each episode of Limitless follows Hemsworth on a unique challenge to push himself to the limits, augmented with interviews with scientific experts on such practices as fasting, extreme temperatures, brain-boosting, and regulating oneâ€™s stress response. Barbor-Might directed the season 1 finale, â€œAcceptance,â€ which was very different in tone, dealing with the inevitability of death and the need to confront oneâ€™s own mortality. â€œIt was really interesting to see Chris in that more intimate personal space, and he was great at it,â€ Barbor-Might told Ars. â€œHe was charâ€¦

items.title: First revealed in spy photos, a Bronze Age city emerges from the steppe
items.summary: An unexpectedly large city lies in a sea of grass inhabited largely by nomads.
items.body: Today all thatâ€™s left of the ancient city of Semiyarka are a few low earthen mounds and some scattered artifacts, nearly hidden beneath the waving grasses of the Kazakh Steppe, a vast swath of grassland that stretches across northern Kazakhstan and into Russia. But recent surveys and excavations reveal that 3,500 years ago, this empty plain was a bustling city with a thriving metalworking industry, where nomadic herders and traders might have mingled with settled metalworkers and merchants. Radivojevic and Lawrence stand on the site of Semiyarka. Credit: Peter J. Brown Welcome to the City of Seven Ravines University College of London archaeologist Miljana Radivojevic and her colleagues recently mapped the site with drones and geophysical surveys (like ground-penetrating radar, for example), tracing the layout of a 140-hectare city on the steppe in whatâ€™s now Kazakhstan. The Bronze Age city once boasted rows of houses built on earthworks, a large central building, and a neighborhood of workshops where artisans smelted and cast bronze. From its windswept promontory, it held a commanding view of a narrow point in the Irtysh River valley, a strategic location that may have offered theâ€¦

In the investor note, seen by 9to5Mac, Pu says that Apple will kick off 2026 with the launch of three new low-cost products: the iPhone 17e, a low-cost MacBook, and anâ€¦

items.title: Newest Starship booster is significantly damaged during testing early Friday
items.summary: SpaceX had big plans for the upgraded Starship vehicle that failed on Friday morning.
items.body: During the pre-dawn hours in South Texas on Friday morning, SpaceXâ€™s next-generation Starship first stage suffered some sort of major damage during pre-launch testing. The company had only rolled the massive rocket out of the factory a day earlier, noting the beginning of its test campaign, it said on the social media site X : â€œThe first operations will test the boosterâ€™s redesigned propellant systems and its structural strength.â€ That testing commenced on Thursday night at the Masseyâ€™s Test Site a couple of miles down the road from the companyâ€™s main production site at Starbase Texas. However an independent video showed the rocketâ€™s lower half undergo an explosive (or possibly implosive) event at 4:04 am CT (10:04 UTC) Friday. Read full article Comments

items.title: Stoke Space goes for broke to solve the only launch problem that â€œmoves the needleâ€
items.summary: "Does the world really need a 151st rocket company?"
items.body: LAUNCH COMPLEX 14, Cape Canaveral, Fla.â€”The platform atop the hulking steel tower offered a sweeping view of Floridaâ€™s rich, sandy coastline and brilliant blue waves beyond. Yet as captivating as the vista might be for an aspiring rocket magnate like Andy Lapsa, it also had to be a little intimidating. To his right, at Launch Complex 13 next door, a recently returned Falcon 9 booster stood on a landing pad. SpaceX has landed more than 500 large orbital rockets. And next to SpaceX sprawled the launch site operated by Blue Origin. Its massive New Glenn rocket is also reusable, and founder Jeff Bezos has invested tens of billions of dollars into the venture. Looking to the left, Lapsa saw a graveyard of sorts for commercial startups. Launch Complex 15 was leased to a promising startup, ABL Space, two years ago. After two failed launches, ABL Space pivoted away from commercial launch. Just beyond lies Launch Complex 16, where Relativity Space aims to launch from. The company has already burned through $1.7 billion in its efforts to reach orbit. Had billionaire Eric Schmidt not stepped in earlier this year, Relativity would have gone bankrupt. Read full article Comments

items.title: HP and Dell disable HEVC support built into their laptopsâ€™ CPUs
items.summary: HEVC licensing gets more expensive in January.
items.body: Some Dell and HP laptop owners have been befuddled by their machinesâ€™ inability to play HEVC/H.265 content in web browsers, despite their machinesâ€™ processors having integrated decoding support. Laptops with sixth-generation Intel Core and later processors have built-in hardware support for HEVC decoding and encoding. AMD has made laptop chips supporting the codec since 2015 . However, both Dell and HP have disabled this feature on some of their popular business notebooks. HP discloses this in the data sheets for its affected laptops, which include the HP ProBook 460 G11 [ PDF ], ProBook 465 G11 [ PDF ], and EliteBook 665 G11 [ PDF] . Read full article Comments

items.title: Infant botulism outbreak doubles; ByHeart confirms bacteria in formula
items.summary: ByHeart said "there's no reason to believe" until its own testing found a reason.
items.body: ByHeart announced on Thursday that its own testing identified the bacterium that causes botulism in its baby formula, which is linked to an ongoing infant botulism outbreak that has doubled since last week. As of November 19, there have been 31 cases across 15 states â€”up from 15 cases in 12 states reported last week. All 31 cases so far have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported. The outbreak was announced on November 8, and ByHeart was, at first, unusually aggressive in deflecting blame for linked illnesses. Read full article Comments

items.title: Microsoft makes Zork I, II, and III open source under MIT License
items.summary: Microsoft's Open Source Programs Office worked with Jason Scott to do it.
items.body: Zork , the classic text-based adventure game of incalculable influence , has been made available under the MIT License, along with the sequels Zork II and Zork III . The move to take these Zork games open source comes as the result of the shared work of the Xbox and Activision teams along with Microsoftâ€™s Open Source Programs Office (OSPO). Parent company Microsoft owns the intellectual property for the franchise. Only the code itself has been made open source. Ancillary items like commercial packaging and marketing assets and materials remain proprietary, as do related trademarks and brands. Read full article Comments

items.title: sit: Create StuffIt archives on Unix systems
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Garibaldi, history's sexiest revolutionary?
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Rapid melt from Antarctica could help preserve crucial ocean current
items.summary: Greenlandâ€™s melt is expected to slow the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, but research suggests a collapse of the West Antarctic ice sheet could in some cases prevent it from shutting down

items.title: Cuts and scrapes may be slower to heal in redheads
items.summary: Mice with the same genetic variant that contributes towards red hair in people were slower to recover from wounds than their black-haired counterparts

items.title: Oldest ever RNA sample recovered from woolly mammoth
items.summary: RNA from an exceptionally well preserved woolly mammoth gives us a window on gene activity in an animal that died nearly 40,000 years ago

items.title: Mystery deepens as isolated galaxy forms stars with no obvious fuel
items.summary: A galaxy in a practically empty area of the universe seems to be impossibly forming stars, and new observations have only deepened the puzzle

items.title: The 19 best Christmas gifts for science lovers (and nerds)
items.summary: From microscopes to geodes, New Scientist staff share their top Christmas present ideas in a gift guide unlike any youâ€™ve seen before

items.title: The forgotten women of quantum physics
items.summary: Physics has a reputation for being dominated by men, especially a century ago, as quantum physics was just being invented â€“ but there have been so many women who helped shaped the field since its inception

items.title: Spectral rendering, part 2: Real-time rendering
items.summary: Comments

items.title: The Inference Economy: Why demand matters more than supply
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Analysing Hitler's DNA for a TV gimmick tells us nothing useful
items.summary: To understand Adolf Hitler, we need to look at his personal life and the wider societal and historical context - analysing his DNA for a TV gimmick tells us nothing, says Michael Le Page

items.title: Why aren't young people having sex any more?
items.summary: Sexual activity in young people is on the decline, but why? And what's more, should we be worried about what this means for society and the future of the human race?

items.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
items.summary: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

items.title: Fossil fuel emissions rise again â€“ but China's are levelling off
items.summary: Global emissions from fossil fuels are expected to hit another record high in 2025, but Chinaâ€™s carbon emissions appear to be reaching a peak

items.title: Strongest evidence yet that the Epstein-Barr virus causes lupus
items.summary: Lupus has been linked to the Epstein-Barr virus â€“ which causes glandular fever, or mono â€“ before, but we now have evidence of how it can bring about the autoimmune condition

items.title: Finally wrangling with the complexity of female bodies benefits us all
items.summary: Medical research has long sought to gloss over the hormonal and chromosomal complications typical of female biology. But embracing this complexity could benefit everyone

items.title: The 19th-century maths that can help you deal with horrible coffee
items.summary: Do you need to fairly allocate players to teams, or sort out a pot of badly brewed coffee? Katie Steckles has a mathematical solution

items.title: Breaking Bad showrunner uses sci-fi for smart dive into happiness
items.summary: Vince Gilligan, the showrunner behind Breaking Bad and Better Call Saul, is back, this time using sci-fi to explore a deceptively rich premise about the pursuit of happiness and the notion of utopia, finds Bethan Ackerley

items.title: New Scientist recommends this extreme birdwatching documentary
items.summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

items.title: Smart new book takes an axe to the myth of human exceptionalism
items.summary: Christine Webb's provocative and moving book The Arrogant Ape explores our unjustifiable sense of superiority in the living world, laying out the evidence against it, says Elle Hunt

items.title: Is the future of education outside universities?
items.summary: New technologies and academic funding cuts are upending the ways we learn today. Newly enrolled student Annalee Newitz finds some silver linings

items.title: Sperm are selfish â€“ and so are we
items.summary: A new study hammers home how the "survival of the nicest" view makes no sense when it comes to evolution, says Jonathan R. Goodman

items.title: Surprising new biography of Francis Crick unravels the story of DNA
items.summary: Francis Crick's biography is full of surprises as author Matthew Cobb reveals the life and work of the co-discoverer of DNA's structure, finds Michael Le Page

items.title: Kim Kardashian has wrangled an invite to NASA HQ. Can we get one too?
items.summary: Reality TV star Kim Kardashian apparently thinks the 1969 moon landing was fake. If Feedback comes up with an equally outlandish conspiracy theory, maybe we can also get a guided tour of NASA

items.title: Remarkable robot images provide a vision of the future
items.summary: These photographs of humanoid robots by Henrik Spohler are part of his project Tomorrow Is the Question

items.title: Sex could help wounds heal faster by reducing stress
items.summary: Mild wounds healed faster if people took a spray containing the "love hormone" oxytocin and set aside time to praise their partner â€“ but they cleared up even quicker if these individuals were also intimate with their other half

items.title: Huge cloud of plasma belched out by star 130 light years away
items.summary: A coronal mass ejection from a distant star has been confirmed for the first time, raising questions about how such events could impact exoplanet habitability

items.title: Is a deadly asteroid about to hit Earth? Meet the man who can tell you
items.summary: When an asteroid threatens Earth, astronomers use a rating called the Torino scale to communicate the risk. Richard Binzel, who invented the scale, tells New Scientist about his 50-year career in planetary defence

items.title: Chemical computer can recognise patterns and perform multiple tasks
items.summary: Previous attempts at building a chemical computer have been too simple, too rigid or too hard to scale, but an approach based on a network of reactions can perform multiple tasks without having to be reconfigured

items.title: Women prefer to be prettier than a partner, but men want to be funnier
items.summary: When measuring yourself against your partner, which traits do you prefer to have compared with your significant other? A survey that forced people to choose has found that men and women have different preferences when it comes to being smarter, funnier or more attractive

items.title: IBM has unveiled two unprecedentedly complex quantum computers
items.summary: IBM revealed two new quantum computers, called Loon and Nighthawk â€“ the qubits they use are connected in newly intricate ways and may enable a way to run error-free computations

items.title: Cradle of humanity is still revealing new insights about our origins
items.summary: The Omo-Turkana basin in Africa is home to a treasure trove of ancient human fossils and tools that span 300,000 years â€“ today it is still yielding new discoveries about our species

items.title: At-home hypnosis relieves menopausal hot flushes
items.summary: Hot flushes could be relieved by listening to recordings that induce hypnosis from home, rather than having to venture to a clinic

items.title: Women have supercharged immune systems and we now know why
items.summary: Being born with two X chromosomes brings a host of health benefits, and recognising this could lead to personalised medical treatments for men and women

items.title: Static electricity can remove frost from windows using little energy
items.summary: High-voltage copper plates can remove up to three-quarters of frost from a surface, while using much less energy than conventional heating

items.title: Odds of asteroid 2024 YR4 hitting the moon may rise to 30 per cent
items.summary: In February, the James Webb Space Telescope will briefly be able to observe asteroid 2024 YR4, which currently has a 4 per cent chance of hitting the moon in 2032. Depending on what it sees, the odds of collision could drastically increase

items.title: The biggest controversy in maths could be settled by a computer
items.summary: For over a decade, mathematicians have failed to agree whether a 500-page proof is actually correct. Now, translating the proof into a computer-readable form may finally settle the matter

items.title: Caves carved by water on Mars may hold signs of past life
items.summary: Eight possible cave openings found on the Martian surface look to have once had ancient streams flowing into them, suggesting they are promising places to look for evidence of life

items.title: Why giving up on goals is good for you, and how to know which to ditch
items.summary: We admire grit and perseverance, but surprising research suggests that giving up on ambitions in the right way can actually improve our physical and mental health

items.title: Falling asleep isnâ€™t a gradual process â€“ it happens all of a sudden
items.summary: Brain activity from more than 1000 people shows a rapid transition from being awake to being asleep, rather than a slow transition between the two states

items.title: AI may blunt our thinking skills â€“ hereâ€™s what you can do about it
items.summary: There is growing evidence that our reliance on generative AI tools is reducing our ability to think clearly and critically, but it doesnâ€™t have to be that way

items.title: Could electric race cars soon be faster than Formula 1?
items.summary: The electric cars of the Formula E racing championship can accelerate faster than Formula 1 cars and their top speeds are catching up â€“ but battery capacity would let them down in a head-to-head

items.title: When rift lakes dry up it can cause earthquakes and eruptions
items.summary: Lake Turkana in Kenya, known as the cradle of humanity, has shrunk in recent millennia â€“ and the loss of water has led to increased seismic activity, which could have impacted our ancient ancestors

items.title: AI power use forecast finds the industry far off track to net zero
items.summary: Several large tech firms that are active in AI have set goals to hit net zero by 2030, but a new forecast of the energy and water required to run large data centres shows theyâ€™re unlikely to meet those targets

items.title: The engrossing biopic of a Hollywood icon's early years
items.summary: Based on a true story, starring Toby Jones, Lesley Manville and Harry Lawtey

items.title: Mysterious holes in Andean mountain may be an Inca spreadsheet
items.summary: Thousands of holes arranged in a snake-like pattern on Monte Sierpe in Peru could have been a monumental accounting device for trade and tax

items.title: James Watson, co-discoverer of DNAâ€™s double helix, has died aged 97
items.summary: As one of the most influential scientists of the 20th century, James Watson pioneered the field of genetics and left behind a complicated legacy

items.title: Enceladusâ€™s ocean may be even better for life than we realised
items.summary: The buried ocean on Saturnâ€™s moon Enceladus seems to be stable across extremely long periods of time, making it an even more promising place to hunt for life

items.title: Having children plays a complicated role in the rate we age
items.summary: The effort of reproducing may divert energy away from repairing DNA or fighting illness, which could drive ageing, but a new study suggests that is only the case when environmental conditions are tough

items.title: A distant galaxy is being strangled by the cosmic web
items.summary: A dwarf galaxy 100 million light years away is being stripped of its crucial star-forming gas, and it seems that the cosmic web is siphoning off this gas as the galaxy passes through

items.title: We may never figure out where interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS came from
items.summary: The surface of comet 3I/ATLAS may have been so radically altered by cosmic rays that deducing its home star system would be impossible

items.title: A three-legged lion has learned to hunt in a completely unexpected way
items.summary: Jacob, an 11-year-old lion, has defied expectations by surviving for years after losing a leg â€“ now we know his success is down to an innovative hunting strategy

items.title: Digital map lets you explore the Roman Empire's vast road network
items.summary: Archaeologists have compiled the most detailed map yet of roads throughout the Roman Empire in AD 150, totalling almost 300,000 kilometres in length

items.title: Grafting trick could let us gene-edit a huge variety of plants
items.summary: Many plants including cocoa, coffee and avocado cannot be gene-edited but a technique involving grafting could change that, opening the door to more productive and nutritious varieties

items.title: Is the expansion of the universe slowing down?
items.summary: It is widely accepted that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate, but now researchers say our measurements of the mysterious force driving that may be wrong and that the universe began to slow 1.5 billion years ago â€“ yet other scientists disagree

items.title: New quantum computer is on the path to unravelling superconductivity
items.summary: Using the Helios-1 quantum computer, researchers have used a record-breaking number of error-proof qubits to run the first and biggest quantum simulation of a model for perfect conductivity

items.title: Here's how to spot the Leonid meteor shower this month
items.summary: A new moon on 20 November means there is a great opportunity to enjoy the Leonid meteor shower this year, says Abigail Beall. Just make sure to get warm and comfy first

items.title: New Scientist recommends the cult film Hackers â€“ 30 years late
items.summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

items.title: New book tells compelling tale of the fight to save the Siberian tiger
items.summary: The battle to save the magnificent but endangered Amur tiger detailed in Jonathan Slaght's Tigers Between Empires is an inspiring look at what collaboration across borders can achieve, finds Adam Weymouth

items.title: Is a robot programmed to prank you annoying? Yes
items.summary: Feedback discovers a robot that can mimic Turkish ice cream vendors, who are known for playing tricks on their customers. Researchers concluded that customers, perhaps predictably, don't trust it

items.title: This book is a great insight into the new science of microchimerism
items.summary: Lise BarnÃ©oud's Hidden Guests shows how this fascinating new field brings with it profound implications for medicine, and even what it means to be human, finds Helen Thomson

items.title: Human minds abhor uncertainty. This is a problem for liberal democracy
items.summary: Neurologically, the flexibility of the future promised by liberal democracy can be a challenge because it brings with it uncertainty. But there are solutions, say Florence Gaub and Liya Yu

items.title: Deep-space sci-fi novel is delightful, profound and not to be missed
items.summary: A planet is about to be destroyed by the collapse of a binary star system in Slow Gods, Claire Northâ€™s first venture into classic science fiction. Read it! says Emily H. Wilson

items.title: What weâ€™re learning about consciousness from master meditatorsâ€™ brains
items.summary: Neuroscientist Matthew Sacchet is revealing how mastering meditation can not only enable transcendental states of bliss, but also reshape how we experience pain and emotion

items.title: Ancient DNA may rewrite the story of Iceland's earliest settlers
items.summary: Biochemical evidence suggests Norse people settled in Iceland almost 70 years before the accepted arrival date of the 870s, and didn't chop down the island's forests

items.title: How preppers plan to save us if the whole internet collapses
items.summary: Recent outages have revealed how vulnerable the internet is, but there seems to be no official plan in the event of a catastrophic failure. Meet the team of hackers who are ready to jump into action

items.title: Our bodies are ageing faster than ever. Can we hit the brakes?
items.summary: All over the world people are ageing more rapidly and succumbing to diseases that typically affected the elderly. But there are ways to turn back the clock on your biological age

items.title: 'I deeply hurt people by moving to Saudi Arabia'
